content.description:
CLOVE* PRICES IN SOUTHEAST ASIA AND IN AMSTERDAM, 1580–1850

(in Spanish silver reals, a common trade currency in the East Indies)

*Cloves are spices native to the Moluccas islands in eastern Indonesia and, until the late eighteenth century, grown only in Southeast Asia.

Source: David Bulbeck, Anthony Reid, Lay Cheng Tan, and Yiqi Wu, eds. Southeast Asian Exports Since the 14th Century: Cloves, Pepper, Coffee, and Sugar, (Leiden, The Netherlands, KITLV Press), 1988. Graph 2.2., p. 57
content.question: Based on the chart and your knowledge of world history, which of the following most directly enabled the Dutch to establish and enforce a monopoly on the Southeast Asian clove trade in the seventeenth century?

choices.label: The nutritional benefits of the Columbian Exchange
The development of powerful joint-stock commercial companies
Dutch advances in mapmaking and navigational skills
Advances in medicine that improved Europeans’ ability to survive tropical diseases

content.answer: The development of powerful joint-stock commercial companies

skill.text: Skill 5.B: Explain how a historical development or process relates to another historical development or process.
